notes: The last decade has delivered exceptional vintages despite challenges, with 2012-2016 producing stellar Cabernets even through drought conditions, while 2017 and 2020 faced devastating wildfires that created smoke taint issues for many producers. Look for 2007, 2012, 2013, 2016, and 2018 Cabernet Sauvignons which showcase Napa's perfect balance of power and elegance, with 2012 and 2016 being particularly legendary for their concentration and aging potential.

The past decade has seen increasingly varied conditions across Sonoma's diverse microclimates, with cool coastal areas producing exceptional Pinot Noirs in 2012, 2014, and 2019, while warmer years like 2013 and 2015 challenged vintners but ultimately yielded concentrated, powerful wines before fire impacts in 2017 and 2020. Seek out 2007, 2009, 2012, 2014, and 2019 Pinot Noirs from Russian River Valley, plus 2013 and 2016 Zinfandels from Dry Creek Valley, which represent Sonoma at its most expressive and balanced.

The last decade has produced some of Oregon's finest vintages ever, with warmer years like 2014, 2015, and 2018 yielding richer, more concentrated Pinots, while cooler vintages like 2016 and 2019 showcased the valley's classic elegance and bright acidity. Hunt for 2008, 2012, 2014, 2015, 2016, and 2018 Pinot Noirs, with 2015 and 2018 offering exceptional ripeness and complexity while 2016 delivers that quintessential Willamette finesse and age-worthiness.

The past decade has been remarkably consistent for Columbia Valley, with its continental climate and irrigation protecting against weather extremes, producing excellent vintages in 2012, 2014, 2016, and 2019, though 2020-2021 faced some heat spike challenges. Focus on 2007, 2010, 2012, 2014, 2016, and 2019 Cabernet Sauvignons and Syrahs, which showcase Washington's signature combination of ripe fruit concentration with fresh acidity and structural precision.

The last decade has seen Mendoza navigate extreme weather with increasing hail events and vintage variation, though high-altitude sites produced exceptional Malbecs in 2013, 2016, 2017, and 2019 with perfect ripeness and balanced acidity. Target 2006, 2010, 2013, 2016, 2017, and 2019 Malbecs and Cabernet-based blends, with 2013 and 2016 offering legendary concentration and aging potential that rival the world's best reds at a fraction of the price.

The past decade has brought challenging drought conditions and heat spikes to South Australia, though regions like Eden Valley and Adelaide Hills have adapted well, with 2012, 2018, and 2021 producing exceptional Shiraz and Cabernet despite the warming trends. Seek out 2005, 2010, 2012, 2013, 2018, and 2021 Barossa Shiraz and Coonawarra Cabernet, with 2012 and 2018 showing remarkable balance between South Australia's signature power and newfound elegance.

The last decade has seen New Zealand's red wine regions, particularly Hawke's Bay and Central Otago, mature significantly with 2013, 2014, 2016, and 2019 producing outstanding Pinot Noirs and Bordeaux-style blends, though vintage variation remains high due to maritime influences. Look for 2010, 2013, 2014, 2016, and 2019 Central Otago Pinot Noirs plus Hawke's Bay Syrahs from the same years, which demonstrate New Zealand's evolution from fruit-forward wines to complex, terroir-driven expressions.

The past decade in Burgundy has been marked by climate extremes including devastating hail, frost, and heat spikes, with 2015, 2019, and 2020 producing rich, concentrated wines while 2014, 2016, and 2017 suffered from severely reduced yields but exceptional quality for those who managed to produce. The unpredictability has made great Burgundy even scarcer and more expensive, with some vintages like 2016 and 2021 losing up to 70% of normal production to frost. Pursue 2005, 2009, 2010, 2015, 2019, and 2020 for reds (with 2019 being potentially legendary), while 2014 and 2017 offer exceptional quality in a more classical, elegant style for those lucky enough to find bottles.

The last decade on the Left Bank has produced several exceptional vintages despite challenging weather, with 2015, 2016, 2018, and 2019 delivering powerful, age-worthy Cabernet Sauvignon-based wines, while 2013, 2014, and 2017 proved more challenging with rain and frost issues. The legendary 2016 vintage stands out for its perfect balance and structure, rivaling the great 2010, while 2018 and 2019 offer contrasting styles - the former rich and opulent, the latter fresh and precise. Hunt for 2005, 2009, 2010, 2015, 2016, 2018, and 2019 from Pauillac and Saint-Estèphe, with 2010 and 2016 destined to become legendary vintages that will drink beautifully for 30+ years.

The Right Bank's Merlot-based wines have thrived in the warmer conditions of the last decade, with 2015, 2016, 2018, and 2019 producing sumptuous, velvety Pomerols and Saint-Émilions, though 2017 suffered devastating spring frosts that decimated yields. The clay soils of Pomerol and limestone slopes of Saint-Émilion have proven more resilient to climate extremes than the Left Bank's gravel, with 2015 and 2018 producing particularly hedonistic wines. Seek out 2005, 2009, 2010, 2015, 2016, and 2018 Pomerol and Saint-Émilion, with 2015 offering immediate pleasure and 2016 combining ripeness with classical structure for long-term aging.

The last decade in Champagne has seen warmer conditions producing riper base wines with 2012, 2013, 2015, 2018, and 2019 declared as excellent vintages, though climate change has actually helped this traditionally marginal region achieve better ripeness levels more consistently. Look for vintage Champagnes from 2002, 2004, 2008, 2012, 2013, and 2015, with 2008 being hailed as potentially the vintage of the century for its perfect balance of ripeness and electric acidity.

The past decade has brought more consistent warmth to Rioja with 2015, 2016, and 2019 producing exceptional, concentrated wines, while 2017 suffered from spring frost reducing yields but concentrating quality in this traditionally reliable region. Seek out 2001, 2004, 2005, 2010, 2015, 2016, and 2019 Gran Reservas and top Reservas, with 2010 and 2016 representing modern Rioja at its finest - balancing traditional elegance with contemporary richness.

The last decade in Tuscany has delivered several outstanding vintages with 2015, 2016, and 2019 producing legendary Brunellos and Chianti Classicos, while 2014 and 2017 proved more challenging with excessive rain and heat spikes respectively, though top producers still crafted excellent wines. Hunt for 2004, 2006, 2010, 2015, 2016, and 2019 Brunello di Montalcino and top Chianti Classico Riservas, with 2010 and 2016 being considered generational vintages offering both power and elegance.

The past decade in Piedmont has produced some historic Barolo and Barbaresco vintages, with 2013, 2016, and 2019 achieving perfect ripeness and balance, while 2014's cool, wet conditions and 2017's heat and drought created more variable quality requiring careful producer selection. Seek out 2004, 2006, 2010, 2013, 2016, and 2019 Barolos and Barbarescos, with 2010 and 2016 representing monumental vintages that combine Nebbiolo's trademark tannins and acidity with exceptional fruit concentration for 30+ years of aging potential.
